In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Sure, here is the code snippet in Julia:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump::Int = 3)
    if typeof(dt) === DateTime
        return dt + Hour(bump)
    elseif typeof(dt) === Date
        throw(ArgumentError("Date type is not allowed. Only DateTime type is allowed."))
    end
end
```
This function takes a `DateTime` and an optional argument `bump`. It checks if the provided date-time object is of type `DateTime`. If it's true, then it adds the hours provided by the user (default is 3) to that date. If not, it throws an error because `Date` types are not allowed in this function.
